program codeforces_421_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, a, b, i, j
    integer, allocatable :: list1(:), list2(:)
    logical :: found

    read *, n, a, b

    allocate(list1(a))
    allocate(list2(b))

    read *, (list1(i), i=1, a)
    read *, (list2(i), i=1, b) do i = 1, n
        found = .false. do j = 1, a
            if (list1(j) == i) then
                found = .true. exit
            end if
        end do
        if (found) then
            write(*, '(I0, A)', advance='no') 1, ' '
        else
            write(*, '(I0, A)', advance='no') 2, ' '
        end if
    end do

    !

Then, the code would be as follows. But how to handle the advance='no' and ensure that all writes are part of the same line. Putting it all together:

The code will read the inputs, check for each i in 1..n, loop through list1 to see if it's present, and output 1 or 2 followed by a space, using advance='no'. So the code would look like this:

program codeforces_421_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, a, b, i, j, num
    integer, allocatable :: list1(:), list2(:)
    logical :: found

    read *, n, a, b

    allocate(list1(a))
    allocate(list2(b))

    read (*, *) list1
    read (*, *) list2

    do i = 1, n
        found = .false. do j = 1, a
            if (list1(j) == i) then
                found = .true. exit
            end if
        end do
        if (found) then
            num = 1
        else
            num = 2
        end if
        write(*, '(I0, A)', advance='no') num, ' '
    end do

    deallocate(list1)
    deallocate(list2)
end program codeforces_421_A

This code reads list1 and list2 using list-directed input (read (*, *) list1), which is okay as long as the input is given correctly.

program codeforces_421_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, a, b, i, j
    integer, allocatable :: list1(:), list2(:)
    logical :: found

    read *, n, a, b

    allocate(list1(a))
    allocate(list2(b))

    read *, (list1(i), i=1, a)
    read *, (list2(i), i=1, b)

    do i = 1, n
        found = .false.
        do j = 1, a
            if (list1(j) == i) then
                found = .true.
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (found) then
            write(*, '(I0, A)', advance='no') 1, ' '
        else
            write(*, '(I0, A)', advance='no') 2, ' '
        end if
    end do

    ! Print a newline after the loop
    print *

    deallocate(list1)
    deallocate(list2)
end program codeforces_421_A

The code will read the inputs, check for each i in 1..n, loop through list1 to see if it's present, and output 1 or 2 followed by a space, using advance='no'. 

So the code would look like this:

program codeforces_421_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, a, b, i, j, num
    integer, allocatable :: list1(:), list2(:)
    logical :: found

    read *, n, a, b

    allocate(list1(a))
    allocate(list2(b))

    read (*, *) list1
    read (*, *) list2

    do i = 1, n
        found = .false.
        do j = 1, a
            if (list1(j) == i) then
                found = .true.
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (found) then
            num = 1
        else
            num = 2
        end if
        write(*, '(I0, A)', advance='no') num, ' '
    end do

    deallocate(list1)
    deallocate(list2)
end program codeforces_421_A

This code reads list1 and list2 using list-directed input (read (*, *) list1), which is okay as long as the input is given correctly. Then, for each i from 1 to n, it checks if i is in list1. If so, outputs 1 and a space, else 2 and a space. 

The writes use advance='no', so they all appear on the same line. However, after the loop, there's no newline. But when the program terminates, the Fortran runtime may or may not add a newline. 

But in practice, the code may or may not pass the test cases depending on whether the judge accepts a trailing newline.
